body: Nice catch!

@DiegoEliasCosta Thanks for taking the time to look into this!

 I'll second the suggestion from @clintropolis, I think this benchmark should really be removed.
Okay, I'm starting the release process for 0.13.0 now so we can keep the 0.13.1 milestone for this one.
Can you add a test for this?

Three days have elapsed. Merging

If `druid.generic.useDefaultValueForNull` is set to false, will the produced segments be incompatible with versions of Druid before 0.13.0?

Have you got units configured correctly? Cpu/time is nanoseconds while
query/time is millisecond

On Sun, 14 Oct 2018, 9:03 am QiuMM, <notifications@github.com> wrote:

> [image: lark20181014-160152]
> <https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/15156517/46914044-98480400-cfca-11e8-8c48-e891c608ee00.png>
> Is this normal?
>
> ‚Äî
> You are receiving this because you are subscribed to this thread.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> <https://github.com/apache/incubator-druid/issues/6465>, or mute the
> thread
> <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AC9pB3WdcS5fwupAXRwsprzd6H8eTNssks5uku_bgaJpZM4XbA0k>
> .
>

Yes, of course. And in fact, query/time is [millisecond](https://github.com/apache/incubator-druid/blob/e3397ba00ff6c439b3fb97a8da1e5e27f1cf301a/processing/src/main/java/org/apache/druid/query/DefaultQueryMetrics.java#L201) while query/cpu/time is [microsecond](https://github.com/apache/incubator-druid/blob/e3397ba00ff6c439b3fb97a8da1e5e27f1cf301a/processing/src/main/java/org/apache/druid/query/DefaultQueryMetrics.java#L237).
Okay then! I just removed LoadStatusBenchmark class from the codebase.

The first version of Oak (0.1.3) is deployed in Maven Central, and the druid pom file is updated to retrieve it.
However 0.1.3 does not support yet off heap buffers greater than 2GB, so don't try benchmarking at scale. 
We will soon deploy a new version that will allow tests with larger memory. Will update when it happens.

> recommend updating the logic in the computeCost method of org.apache.druid.server.coordinator.CostBalancerStrategy

@clintropolis Based on _Loose coupling_ approach, I strive to make as less changes to existing entities as possible, here I had to change `DruidCoordinatorBalancer`, as it has to know about maintenance servers, but I still can leave `BalancerStrategy` intact as it can operate correctly without that knowledge.
@egor-ryashin thanks for review
@gianm included the points you mentioned in the PR description

>Support for 64-bit floating point columns was release in Druid 0.11.0, so if this is enabled, versions older than 0.11.0 will not be able to read the data segments.

this was a little confusing when i read this first.

please consider rephrasing to:

```
64-bit doubles aggregators are now used by default (see #5478). Support for 64-bit floating point columns was only released in Druid 0.11.0.

If you are upgrading from a version older than 0.11 directly to 0.13,  your nodes will not be able to read the data segments. Thus, for users upgrading from version older than 0.11, either:

1.  disable and keep the old format. For this, you will need to set the system-wide property druid.indexing.doubleStorage=float.

2. First upgrade to 0.11, and then to 0.13


```

@pdeva thank you for the comment! maybe @nishantmonu51 can confirm, but I don't think that's exactly accurate. 0.13 will not have trouble reading segments generated before 0.11; the issue is that since the 64-bits doubles aggregator was added in 0.11, if you enabled this feature and then rolled back to a version of Druid prior to 0.11.0, that's when you would run into compatibility issues. Is the comment more clear now with that context?

i am actually more confused now.

is this correct, in a gist:

- if you are upgrading from druid 0.11 or 0.12, you dont need to worry.
- if you are upgrading from < 0.11, things may go bad if:
xxxxxx

LGTM

@clintropolis Well, that way we would have to change all `BalancerStrategy` subclasses (ie `RandomBalancerStrategy`), moreover `BroadcastDistributionRule` doesn't use `BalancerStrategy` and have to be changed anyway. But most of all, by calling `BalancerStrategy` for each segment, it is inefficient to iterate all the servers each time to check for the flag, if you can partition them beforehand and filter them out. 
Yes, `LoadRule` can drop a segment from an available node first indeed, that's a good catch. Still, it only matters when a node with a somewhat old cache is started and contains a segment already fully replicated somewhere, which is a rare case. The case when `LoadRule` drops a segment when it's out of the specified period rule doesn't matter, as then all the replicas got dropped that way.

There is a use case for having it be different than the sums of the location sizes: let's say you have 3 locations, and each could hold up to 1TB, but you don't want to store more than 2TB on the entire server. This is pretty niche though. So I do think it makes sense for the default druid.server.maxSize to be the sum of the locations, and maybe a small set of people will use a different value.
Have you tried to correlate with overlord logs?
@gianm @leventov thanks for your reviews. Have updated.

We currently have this `after_failure` section in `travis.yml` which dumps the last 100 lines from the logs:

```
      after_failure:
        - for v in ~/shared/logs/*.log ; do
          echo $v logtail ======================== ; tail -100 $v ;
          done
        - for v in broker middlemanager overlord router coordinator historical ; do
          echo $v dmesg ======================== ;
          docker exec -it druid-$v sh -c 'dmesg | tail -3' ;
          done
```

We could try dumping the full logs that way, which has been suggested by someone from Travis CI: https://github.com/travis-ci/travis-ci/issues/7836#issuecomment-305613868

Thanks @jon-wei. I found that the info that I need is already posted in the CI log, I didn't notice that I have to click on small triangle to show it:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/609240/47039505-81d0b280-d15a-11e8-94f7-a218a8337c87.png)

@yurmix thanks for looking into this!

> Once we figure out which the audit rules we can add this into the CheckStyle or to the integration tests.

Hm, deciding whether a non-code binary artifact should be allowed seems pretty subjective and context dependent to me, seems like a Checkstyle rule would be too blunt (My impression is that this really requires a manual case-by-case review).

e.g., would we forbid "zip" files? I think it's reasonable to include sample data for tests in a zip file.

I believe all of these files fall into the following categories:
1. Test data (either binary or packaged textual).
2. Binary content (Image files, PDFs).

I couldn't find any document which states that these types of files are not allowed in a source release (and I found multiple cases where such files exists in the GitHub Apache organization).

Therefore I believe we can close this issue. 

Please review the list and see if you reach the same conclusion:

| File name      | Category |
| :---        |    :----:   |
|./core/src/test/resources/keystore.jks|Test data|
|./processing/src/test/resources/v8SegmentPersistDir/00000.smoosh|Test data|
|./processing/src/test/resources/v8SegmentPersistDir/version.bin|Test data|
|./publications/whitepaper/modii658-yang.zip|Binary content|
|./server/src/main/resources/static/old-console/images/favicon.ico|Binary content|
|./docs/_graphics/druid.graffle|Binary content|
|./examples/quickstart/tutorial/wikiticker-2015-09-12-sampled.json.gz|Test data|
|./indexing-hadoop/src/test/resources/test-segment/index.zip|Test data|
|./extensions-contrib/parquet-extensions/example/wikipedia_list.parquet|Test data|
|./extensions-contrib/parquet-extensions/example/284a0e001476716b-56d5676f53bd6e85_115466471_data.0.parq|Test data|
|./extensions-contrib/parquet-extensions/example/test_date_data.snappy.parquet|Test data|
|./extensions-contrib/time-min-max/src/test/resources/druid.sample.tsv.zip|Test data|
Thanks for your patient reviews, @jihoonson. I have updated the PR with the requested changes. Travis build seems to be timing out.

@pdeva 

- Prior to 0.11, Druid only supported using 32-bit floats for the storage layer and so would not be able to understand segments that used 64-bit doubles.
- After 0.11, Druid now also supports 64-bit doubles for storage, but up until this release, it was still using 32-bit floats by default unless 64-bit doubles were explicitly enabled.
- In this release, 64-bit doubles will now be the default unless `druid.indexing.doubleStorage=float` is set.

Hence, for this specific feature, there is no issue upgrading from previous versions to 0.13, but if you don't explicitly configure 0.13 to use 32-bit floats to store double values, you will not be able to rollback to a version before 0.11.

@gianm I totally agree with your suggestion. 
defaultUsed is only used at Ingestion and there is no need to keep it with DataSegment forever.

I'm planning to remove that change from DataSegment and only keep in HadoopTuningConfig. Does that sounds good to you? 
I'll do some testing internally and update this PR.

So, the new question is, why *this* happens?
[Possibly important note: We're using Overlord inside Coordinator.]
It seems that dropped ZK connection causes Coordinator to loose leadership and in turn perform a pretty thorough restart of everything?

EDIT: We have only one Coordinator running there.

Does not sound very sensible, tbh. I will investigate it more tomorrow, but any thoughts are still welcome.
@gianm Sorry, I have been busy working on other issues. May I apply @jihoonson's comments by this weekend?

I'm closing this PR now because I couldn't spend much time for this issue for a while and finally it has gone too stale. Also, probably there's a better way to not modify too many classes. I'll think about it and make another PR later.
`pullFromCache` merely deserializes the aggregated result from the cache and does not perform further aggregation on it. Therefore, I don't think this change is required.
thanks @dclim

Thank you @yurmix for looking into this. I agree with your conclusion, and think that it makes sense to go ahead with the RC including these files. If our mentors or the incubator PMC expresses any concerns, we can address them at that time. Thanks again!

BTW, I believe, it can pick segments and request to load them while they are requested for drop during a `LoadRule` run.
Thanks for the contributions! Can this be covered in a unit test to show the error case?
i am infact constantly getting 500 errors trying to download anything from static.druid.io
Here's a partial flame graph from some of our hot nodes. I'll be excited if the lz4 decrypt is faster. Even 10% would be good

Sorry about that, this got merged way quicker than I imagined it would, hopefully it's not too painful :(

Since it's mostly just moving files and pom fixup, having [similar settings in place](https://github.com/apache/incubator-druid/pull/6266#issuecomment-417172303) as were needed during the `io.druid.*` rename to `org.apache.druid.*` should make it so things aren't too bad in most cases I hope.
Skipping CI for docs-only change.

@FaxianZhao thanks for the fix! You don't have to rebase any commits in most cases. Once you commit, it's fine to leave them as they are. 

The failing unit tests seem legit. Please check it.

```
java.lang.RuntimeException: java.lang.NullPointerException: actionOnInvalidLocks
```

I'll add more commits to adjust coordinator console after #6415 being merged, because there may be some code conflicts between these two pr.

@hellobabygogo sorry for the delayed review.. I think I still don't fully understand what the fundamental problem is. My questions are:

1) task2 looks suspicious to me. Why was task2 started even though task1 was running?
2) with this PR, the overlord can reject starting the supervisor with a new spec if pendingTaskGroup is not empty. Then, what happens if stream data is continuously ingested and there are always some running and publish pending tasks? Is it possible that this solution can work without pausing stream ingestion?

Probably https://github.com/apache/incubator-druid/issues/6001 can fix this as well. https://github.com/apache/incubator-druid/issues/6001 is to preserve the order of publishing segments, so that early task always publishes its segments earlier than later tasks.
@QiuMM No
@niketh could you please take a look?

One use case I can see some issues is if you have multiple disks which in aggregate have enough free space, but none individually does.

For example, lets say the free spaces for 10 disks were:

100MB, 100MB, 100MB, 100MB, 100MB, 100MB, 100MB, 100MB, 100MB, 100MB

The coordinator might think it can hold 1GB worth of segments, when in reality it can't hold any segment larger than 100MB.

((This might actually be a problem even in the current implementation))

I know I've been bitten by the "disk space has to be set twice" problem a few times. That and the kilobyte vs kibibyte... As this is designed, please be sure to call out any corner cases that may arise. Suggest limiting scope to "sum of disks" problem for now, and leaving measurement in bytes. Anything that is "not worse than current and better in at least these cases" is very welcome.
